values.alignmentText: Protected areas like Los Haitises and Jaragua showcase biodiversity, yet deforestation and waste management issues near Santo Domingo challenge environmental quality.
As a Caribbean nation the DR faces rising hurricane intensity, sea-level rise, and coral bleaching, elevating climate risk for coastal families.
The island experiences a tropical climate with wet and dry seasons; humidity stays high year-round with occasional trade-wind relief.
Vehicle emissions and open burning can raise PM levels in Santo Domingo, though sea breezes generally keep pollution lower than South Asian megacities.
Hurricanes, tropical storms, and occasional earthquakes require robust preparedness and insurance.
March–May temperatures hover between 23–31°C (73–88°F), delivering warm but tolerable days with afternoon showers.
June–August highs reach 32–34°C (90–93°F) with high humidity and hurricane season ramping up, challenging Sarah’s heat tolerance.
September–November remains warm at 23–32°C (73–90°F) with peak storm activity and heavy rainfall.
December–February offers 20–29°C (68–84°F) weather, the most comfortable period for outdoor family activities.
Resort towns like Punta Cana and Las Terrenas deliver idyllic beaches with clear water, family amenities, and snorkel options.
Sea temperatures stay 26–29°C (79–84°F) year-round, enabling consistent swimming and water sports.
Mountain ranges, waterfalls, and cenotes allow quick weekend adventures, though road infrastructure can slow access.
Minimum wages vary by sector from RD$11k–21k/month (~$190–$360), insufficient for comfortable urban living without supplemental income.
Senior developers often earn RD$1.2M–1.6M/year (~$20–27k), making remote US contracts or entrepreneurship more attractive for Trey.
Banks, telecoms, and outsourcing firms in Santo Domingo hire .NET talent, but the market is small and Spanish fluency helps.
Ruby roles are rare; most local startups rely on PHP or JavaScript stacks, so Sarah would depend on remote clients.
Companies seldom sponsor US workers; work permits favor investors or regional professionals with Spanish proficiency.
Tourism rebounds strongly, remittances remain steady, and GDP growth hovers near 4%, yet inequality and reliance on tourism create fragility.
Coworking hubs exist in Santo Domingo and Punta Cana, and fiber internet is available in upscale areas, though power outages necessitate backup plans.
Dominican culture emphasizes family and social life, but service sectors demand long shifts during peak tourist seasons.
Labour laws cap the workweek at 44 hours, yet informal overtime is common in hospitality and call centers.
Employees accrue 14 paid vacation days after a year plus numerous public holidays, which grows with tenure.
Companies often stick to the legal minimum, so negotiated contracts are key for longer breaks.
Island life feels relaxed outside Santo Domingo traffic, aligning with the family’s desire for a slower daily rhythm.
Schools commonly run 8 a.m.–2 p.m., offices 9 a.m.–6 p.m., with extended lunch breaks and evening socializing.
Weekends center on beach trips, baseball games, and family gatherings, creating strong community ties.
Extended families and neighbors offer support networks, though expats must navigate language barriers and socioeconomic divides.
Polyamory is socially stigmatized and lacks legal protection; discretion is necessary to avoid gossip and institutional pushback.
Parents prioritize respect, Catholic traditions, and academic progress, which can feel formal compared with US parenting norms.
Malls and gated communities provide safe play zones, but sidewalks, traffic, and public spaces lag in accessibility.
Bilingual private schools, US-curriculum academies, and public options exist; quality correlates strongly with tuition levels.
Private preschools and nannies are common; public early education capacity is limited in urban zones.
Government daycare programs are sparse, so most families rely on relatives or paid caregivers.
Expat families can hire caregivers affordably, but formal contracts and Spanish fluency help ensure compliance.
Public schools face resource gaps and half-day schedules; higher-income families favor private institutions.
International schools in Santo Domingo and Santiago welcome foreigners but charge high fees and may require placement testing.
Top-tier schools offer US or IB curricula with strong English instruction and extracurriculars, albeit at premium cost.
Maternity leave lasts 14 weeks with partial salary coverage; broader family benefits are limited outside social security.
Foreign employees under formal contracts receive the same statutory leave, but enforcement depends on employer compliance.
Universidad Autónoma de Santo Domingo and private universities provide accessible degrees, though research funding is modest.
Foreign students can enroll with validated documents; instruction is mostly in Spanish, limiting options for English-only speakers.
Traditional gender expectations persist, but urban professionals champion more egalitarian partnerships.
Trans and nonbinary individuals face significant discrimination and limited legal recognition.
Legal protections exist against workplace discrimination, yet enforcement is weak and domestic violence rates remain high.
Feminine presentation emphasizes grooming and style, with societal pressure for women to balance work and homemaking.
Machismo culture values assertiveness and provider roles, though younger generations embrace softer masculinity models.
Afro-Caribbean music, merengue festivals, and syncretic history provide rich storytelling inspiration for Trey.
Spanish dominates; tourism workers speak English but daily bureaucracy and community life require Spanish proficiency.
Urban activists push for anti-corruption and LGBTQ+ rights, yet national policy remains socially conservative with strong church influence.
Leftist parties exist but neoliberal policies dominate; socialism is more academic than mainstream.
Secular viewpoints are tolerated but public life remains religious; being openly atheist is easier in expat circles.
Public discourse is modest despite resort marketing; poly relationships would be considered taboo in most communities.
Pride events occur in Santo Domingo, yet anti-discrimination laws are limited and social acceptance lags outside tourist zones.
Dominicans are famously friendly and quick to include newcomers in gatherings, though socioeconomic disparities can create bubbles.
Citizens take pride in resilience, baseball success, and cultural vibrancy despite economic challenges.
Relations with Haiti are strained over migration and border policy, while ties with Puerto Rico and the US are pragmatic.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Regional neighbors value Dominican tourism leadership but criticize treatment of Haitian migrants.
Merengue clubs, beach bars, and resort lounges keep nightlife lively, with safer experiences in tourist areas than in some urban zones.
Men favor polished casual looks—pressed shirts, jeans, and guayaberas—suited to the tropical climate.
Women embrace colorful dresses and tailored outfits, balancing comfort with elegance suitable for warm evenings.
Baseball, dance, dominoes, and beach outings dominate leisure time, offering easy entry points for socializing.
Board-game cafés are limited but expat groups host tabletop nights in Santo Domingo; imports can be expensive.
Live bachata and merengue performances are ubiquitous, and cultural festivals keep music central to community life.
Entrepreneur groups, digital nomad meetups, and volunteer organizations offer ways to build networks despite the small tech scene.
Within a few hours you can reach surf beaches, mountain hikes in Jarabacoa, or whale watching in Samaná.
The DR is a presidential republic with competitive elections, though clientelism and patronage remain influential.
Catholic and evangelical leaders influence social policy, slowing reforms on reproductive and LGBTQ+ rights.
Labour codes guarantee severance and bonuses, but enforcement in tourism and manufacturing is inconsistent.
Policy blends pro-business tourism incentives with modest social programs aimed at poverty reduction.
Democratic institutions are stable yet susceptible to corruption and executive overreach without vigilant civil society.
A market economy with free zones encourages foreign investment, though monopolies and oligarchic influence persist.
Political transitions are peaceful, but corruption scandals and protests occasionally disrupt normalcy.
Media is privately owned yet politicized; government messaging focuses on tourism success and infrastructure projects.
Campaigns highlight economic growth and public security, but narratives around migration can be nationalistic.
Conditional cash transfer programs and subsidized electricity aim to support low-income families, though coverage gaps remain.
Public trust is moderate; anti-corruption pledges resonate but skepticism persists due to past scandals.
Transparency International ranks the DR mid-pack, with persistent concerns over procurement and police bribery.
Clientelism, kickbacks, and bureaucratic bribes are the most common issues expats encounter.
Modern condos in Santo Domingo and resort towns offer amenities and security, but infrastructure reliability (power, water) varies by neighborhood.
Petty crime, theft, and occasional armed robberies occur, so secure housing, guarded parking, and situational awareness are essential.
Public healthcare provides basic services but lacks resources; private insurers fill gaps for middle-class families.
Private hospitals in Santo Domingo and Santiago deliver quality care with English-speaking staff; expats should maintain international insurance for evacuations.
Affordable domestic help is available, but families must manage training and reliability; formal daycare centers are limited outside major cities.
Middle-class families self-organize support through relatives, nannies, and private schools, balancing community warmth with service gaps.
Educational quality is improving but lags OECD norms; private bilingual schools can deliver strong outcomes with active parental involvement.
Santo Domingo’s metro and bus systems are expanding, but coverage is limited and many residents rely on cars or ride-hailing.
The DR runs an open, service-oriented economy with incentives for tourism and free zones, providing opportunities for entrepreneurs who navigate local regulations.
The tax system includes VAT (ITBIS) and income taxes with frequent reforms; local accountants simplify compliance for expats.
Top marginal income tax reaches 25% with social security contributions; foreign-earned income becomes taxable after tax residency is established.
Banks require residency documents and references; card usage is common in cities, while cash remains important in smaller towns.
Housing and groceries are affordable, but imported goods, private healthcare, and international schooling elevate monthly budgets.
Social security pensions are modest; retirees often rely on family support or private savings.
The DR offers a retiree residency with tax incentives on foreign income, appealing to expats with stable pensions.
Residency by investment, retiree visas, and standard temporary residency paths exist, with streamlined processes for those proving income.
Tourist zones and expat communities welcome Americans, though integrating beyond expat enclaves requires Spanish and cultural sensitivity.
Temporary residency renews annually for up to five years before permanent status; investors and retirees can fast-track approvals.
Citizenship is available after seven years of residency and Spanish proficiency, and dual nationality is permitted.
Dependents obtain derivative residency permits and can work once they secure their own cédula IDs.
Consular applications, in-country medical exams, and translation fees add up, but total costs remain moderate compared with other nations.
Maintaining residency requires annual renewals, local health insurance, and timely tax filings; corruption at migration offices can cause delays.
The DR allows dual citizenship, so the family could keep US passports if naturalizing.
Applicants must secure police certificates, apostilled documents, and in-country guarantors; legal assistance streamlines the process.
The local game industry is nascent, with a handful of studios focused on outsourcing and serious games; opportunities are limited.
Small teams like Mundos Digitales and indie collectives operate in Santo Domingo, but scale is modest.
Game jams at universities and the annual Santo Domingo Game Fest provide networking, though the scene is still emerging.
Access to grants or venture capital is scarce, so Trey would rely on remote clients and export incentives like free-zone status.
Santo Domingo offers fiber internet and a metro, yet power reliability hinges on generators and infrastructure quality drops outside tourist areas.
